SGLT_Ftitle: Salerno. Duomo. Tomba della Regina Marg. di Durazzo
SGTT_OAtitle: Monumento funebre della regina Margherita di Durazzo
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 400x280.
OSS_OAnotes:
Le fotografie che documentano l'opera sono conservate in fascicoli con intestazioni diverse.

Foto sup 991, verso: nota anonima manoscritta: "Queen Margherita widow of Carlo III, who died in 1412. A grand monument by Baboccio. Above the queen reclining on ta sarc. and 4 angels drawing back the costains. On the sarc. in front the queen scaled surrounded by the ladies of her court and her children. On the rear of sarc. the queen scaled amidst 14 huns. The sides have magnificent A[?]. Below 4 virtues support the tomb [...]"
Note: Queen Margherita widow of Carlo III, who died in 1412. A grand monument by Baboccio. Above the queen reclining on ta sarc. and 4 angels drawing back the costains. On the sarc. in front the queen scaled surrounded by the ladies of her court and her children. On the rear of sarc. the queen scaled amidst 14 huns. The sides have magnificent A[?]. Below 4 virtues support the tomb [...]"

SGLT_Ftitle: Cattedrale Amalfi
AUTN_OAaut: Maestranze attive ad Amalfi sec. IX/ XIII
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 380x317.
OSS_OAnotes:
Foto sup 1002, verso: nota anonima manoscritta: "Amalfi. This campanile is said to date from 1153, temp. king Roger, but I much do not; at all wears, the superstructure is much more modern. It has, says Fr. Leuermant, des veritables mosaiques à grandes pieces (lava) incrustees dans l'appareil de gros bloes de Calcaire. Elles dessinent les lions rucupents d'un style tout heraldique. Le lion était l'embleme de la dynastie normande".

Foto sup 1003, verso: nota anonima manoscritta: "Cloister of the Canonica founded in 1213 by Cardinal Pietro Capuano.".

Foto sup 1012, verso: nota anonima manoscritta: "In cloister of Amalfi Duomo. Sarc. of an archbishop of the Capuani family (by the coat) who died about 1350; Pietro Capanno was he called. The relief of the Madonna della Neve is of about 1400; the two Jesuit Saints are of course after 1600".
Note: Amalfi. This campanile is said to date from 1153, temp. king Roger, but I much do not; at all wears, the superstructure is much more modern. It has, says Fr. Leuermant, des veritables mosaiques à grandes pieces (lava) incrustees dans l'appareil de gros bloes de Calcaire. Elles dessinent les lions rucupents d'un style tout heraldique. Le lion était l'embleme de la dynastie normande".

SGLT_Ftitle: Convento S. Francesco. Amalfi
AUTN_OAaut: Maestranze attive ad Amalfi sec. XIII
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 280x400.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 1005, verso: nota anonima manoscritta: "Amalfi. Cloister of San Francesco founded by the Saint himself in 1220. The convent is now the Hotel de la Lana, but the church, tho' of trenewed in stile in use and contains the crypt where the saint lived and where he nonnulla miracula patravit.".
Note: Amalfi. Cloister of San Francesco founded by the Saint himself in 1220. The convent is now the Hotel de la Lana, but the church, tho' of trenewed in stile in use and contains the crypt where the saint lived and where he nonnulla miracula patravit.".

OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 884, verso: nota anonima manoscritta: "Ad matrem Christi qua templo presidet isti / Qui legis ingredere, veniamq; precando merere. / Cum bis centenus ausisset tempora denus / Annus millenus floreret papa Serenus / Imperiiq; decus princeps Otto. Sumere equus / Hec Philippe pie decorasti cum pie Marie. / This is Otto the Guelph Anno 1210".
Note: Ad matrem Christi qua templo presidet isti / Qui legis ingredere, veniamq; precando merere. / Cum bis centenus ausisset tempora denus / Annus millenus floreret papa Serenus / Imperiiq; decus princeps Otto. SGLT_Ftitle: Sarcophagus of Titus Gorgonius
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 317x380.
OSS_OAnotes:
Foto sup 889, verso: nota anonima manoscritta: "Ancona. La cripth of Duomo, S. Ciriaco. Sarcophagus of Titus Gorgonius, precetor of / Ancona and of his wife. The wedded pair are represented on the / front as crowding at the feet of Christ, on the back / in a medallion embraing one another. //

The inscription says: T.L. Gorgonius vc ex comite largitionum privatarum exp. pret. fie. sibi pus. The [...]".
Note: Ancona. La cripth of Duomo, S. Ciriaco. Sarcophagus of Titus Gorgonius, precetor of / Ancona and of his wife. The wedded pair are represented on the / front as crowding at the feet of Christ, on the back / in a medallion embraing one another. //

AUTB_Fsubj_main: Scuola italiana, scuola ravennate/ scuola costantinopolitana
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 316x382.
OSS_OAnotes:
Foto sup 128, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Christian sarcophagus of the 5 th. century representing Jesus Christ / seated, between two standing disciples, in a chair with his feet / resting on the lion and the basilic. The palm trees mean / that this took place in Judea. / The sarcophagus, which is at Ravenna, is now under cover near / S. Francesco. In the middle ages it became the burial place / of the Pignatta, who fashioned the corner ornaments of the lid / with pots (pignatte) their canting arms".

Foto sup 183, verso: nota anonima manoscritta: "Ravenna. / Exterior of S. Francesco, when / Dante was buried. / The two ends of the sarcophagus used by the Pignatti. / The Annunciation and perhaps the espousals of Joseph & Mary. / Says Kraus: of circa 420 und von grosser Bedetung. [...] Engel; Aus dem Apocrypha".
Note: Christian sarcophagus of the 5 th. century representing Jesus Christ / seated, between two standing disciples, in a chair with his feet / resting on the lion and the basilic. The palm trees mean / that this took place in Judea. / The sarcophagus, which is at Ravenna, is now under cover near / S. Francesco. In the middle ages it became the burial place / of the Pignatta, who fashioned the corner ornaments of the lid / with pots (pignatte) their canting arms".

D. 1321. / Raynaldo de Mediolano de domo Corrigio, homo sancta et honesta / vita, qui nulla miracula fecit. Suo tempore constructa est de novo / tota navis ecclesiae ursianae et balena Ravenna [...] est in ripa maris. / Sepultus est in eccl. maj. de Ravenna in arca juncta altare / S. Maria in medio eccl".

Aprelis. cuy. ani. requiescat ...".

MCCCXXXV die XXV mense septembris undic. V. cupus anima requiescat in pace. His jacet dominus Loffridus Filumarinus senescal. dni. ducis Calabrie qui obiit anno MCCCXXXV die quarto decimo mens. Aprelis. cuy. ani. requiescat ...".
Note: Monument to Charles of Angon, who died in 1285, So Karl Martel, king of Hungary, Dantes friend, who died in 1301; To Clementina his wife (+1295), daughter of Kaiser Rudolf. It was put up by the Viceroy Olivares in 1599".

SGLT_Ftitle: Ravenna. Exterior of S. Francesco, when Dante was buried. The two ends of the sarcophagus used by the Pignatti
AUTB_Fsubj_main: Scuola italiana, scuola ravennate/ scuola costantinopolitana
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 316x380.
OSS_OAnotes:
Foto sup 128, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Christian sarcophagus of the 5 th. century representing Jesus Christ / seated, between two standing disciples, in a chair with his feet / resting on the lion and the basilic. The palm trees mean / that this took place in Judea. / The sarcophagus, which is at Ravenna, is now under cover near / S. Francesco. In the middle ages it became the burial place / of the Pignatta, who fashioned the corner ornaments of the lid / with pots (pignatte) their canting arms".

Foto sup 183, verso: nota anonima manoscritta: "Ravenna. / Exterior of S. Francesco, when / Dante was buried. / The two ends of the sarcophagus used by the Pignatti. / The Annunciation and perhaps the espousals of Joseph & Mary. / Says Kraus: of circa 420 und von grosser Bedetung. [...] Engel; Aus dem Apocrypha".
Note: Ravenna. / Exterior of S. Francesco, when / Dante was buried. / The two ends of the sarcophagus used by the Pignatti. / The Annunciation and perhaps the espousals of Joseph & Mary. / Says Kraus: of circa 420 und von grosser Bedetung. [...] Engel; Aus dem Apocrypha".

SGLT_Ftitle: Napoli. Chiesa S. Domenico Maggiore. Tomba di Giovanna d'Aquino

OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 1140, verso: nota anonima manoscritta: "Gothic tomb of Giovanna d'Aquino, Countess of Mileto and Terranuova, who died in 1345 Below in the sarcophagus and inscription of a boy of the Aquino family, Gaspare, who died in 1530 and who, Mr. Hare says, was her son!!".
Note: Gothic tomb of Giovanna d'Aquino, Countess of Mileto and Terranuova, who died in 1345 Below in the sarcophagus and inscription of a boy of the Aquino family, Gaspare, who died in 1530 and who, Mr. Hare says, was her son!!".

SGLT_Ftitle: Ravenna. Exterior of S. Francesco, when Dante was buried. Rear of Pignatti Sarcophagus
AUTB_Fsubj_main: Scuola italiana, scuola ravennate/ scuola costantinopolitana
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 316x380.
OSS_OAnotes:
Foto sup 128, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Christian sarcophagus of the 5 th. century representing Jesus Christ / seated, between two standing disciples, in a chair with his feet / resting on the lion and the basilic. The palm trees mean / that this took place in Judea. / The sarcophagus, which is at Ravenna, is now under cover near / S. Francesco. In the middle ages it became the burial place / of the Pignatta, who fashioned the corner ornaments of the lid / with pots (pignatte) their canting arms".

Foto sup 183, verso: nota anonima manoscritta: "Ravenna. / Exterior of S. Francesco, when / Dante was buried. / The two ends of the sarcophagus used by the Pignatti. / The Annunciation and perhaps the espousals of Joseph & Mary. / Says Kraus: of circa 420 und von grosser Bedetung. [...] Engel; Aus dem Apocrypha".

SGLT_Ftitle: Ravenna. Sant'Apollinare in Classe. The two ends of the sarcophagus of S. Teodoro, archibishop.
AUTB_Fsubj_main: Scuola italiana, scuola romagnola, scuola ravennate
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 316x380.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 171, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Ravenna. / Basilica Ursiana. / Sarcophagus of S. Rinaldo, Archibishop of Ravenna. This is of the fifth century but S. Rinaldo himself died A. D. 1321. / Raynaldo de Mediolano de domo Corrigio, homo sancta et honesta / vita, qui nulla miracula fecit. Suo tempore constructa est de novo / tota navis ecclesiae ursianae et balena Ravenna [...] est in ripa maris. / Sepultus est in eccl. maj. de Ravenna in arca juncta altare / S. Maria in medio eccl".

OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 316x380.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 188, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "The so called Apotheosis of Augustus - Sacresty San Vitale Ravenna. / I think it represents the Julian family: / Julius seated (much like an old woman), Augustus in armour, / Drusus, Livia and Tiberius. The figure in armour resembles the / statue found at Prima Porta ad Gallinas Albas".
Note: The so called Apotheosis of Augustus - Sacresty San Vitale Ravenna. / I think it represents the Julian family: / Julius seated (much like an old woman), Augustus in armour, / Drusus, Livia and Tiberius. The figure in armour resembles the / statue found at Prima Porta ad Gallinas Albas".

OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 1157, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Marie de Valois was the wife of Duke Charles of Calabria. She died in 1328. She is represented in a blue mantle. Note: Marie de Valois was the wife of Duke Charles of Calabria. She died in 1328. She is represented in a blue mantle. The tomb is of a quiet, lifeless, but comparatively correct style, says Mr. Perkins. It is by an artist of the Tuscan school, probably a follower of Tino da Camaino".

OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 1167, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Monument of King Ladislaus in S. Giovanni Carbonara, Naples. It is said to have been executed by Andrea Ciccione in 1433. It is transitional and therefore interesting in the history of art. It is in three divisions. Below, three virtues; then Ladislav and his sister, queen Joanna II, who ordered the tomb, seated; above the sarcophagus ...".
Note: Monument of King Ladislaus in S. Giovanni Carbonara, Naples. It is said to have been executed by Andrea Ciccione in 1433. It is transitional and therefore interesting in the history of art. It is in three divisions. Below, three virtues; then Ladislav and his sister, queen Joanna II, who ordered the tomb, seated; above the sarcophagus ...".

SGLT_Ftitle: Bologna - Chiesa di S. Giacomo Maggiore. Ritratto di Annibale Bentivoglio (attribuito a Niccolò da Bari detto dell'Arca).

OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 381x317.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 283, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Hannibal Bentivoglio slain by the Canedoli in 1458. / Quo nemo utilior patrie nec pace nec armis / Bentivole gentis Hannibal hic situs est / Expulit is dudum possessa ex urbe tirannum / Ut profugos cives restitutus patriae / A quibus ingratae sceleratu monte peremptus / Sed meritum sumptis factio supplicium / Nam sceleris tanti affinis quicumque fuisset / Hic ferro aut flamma oremia digna tulit".
Note: Hannibal Bentivoglio slain by the Canedoli in 1458. / Quo nemo utilior patrie nec pace nec armis / Bentivole gentis Hannibal hic situs est / Expulit is dudum possessa ex urbe tirannum / Ut profugos cives restitutus patriae / A quibus ingratae sceleratu monte peremptus / Sed meritum sumptis factio supplicium / Nam sceleris tanti affinis quicumque fuisset / Hic ferro aut flamma oremia digna tulit".

SGLT_Ftitle: Bologna - Cimitero della Certosa. Monumento Malvezzi (Francesco di Simone Fiorentino).
SGTT_OAtitle: Monumento funebre di Piriteo Malvezzi Lupari, già di Pietro Fieschi
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 381x316.
OSS_OAnotes:
Foto sup 285, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Of the same period as the Tartagna monument in S. Domenico 1477. / The inscription is that of one the Malvezzi family who died / in this century".

La foto sup 285 documenta l'allestimento tardo ottocentesco del monumento nel chiostro del '500 della Certosa.

La lunetta con l'Allegoria della Carità, realizzata da Giacomo De Maria, documentata dalla foto è oggi perduta. 

A De Maria si deve anche l'esecuzione del ritratto di Piriteo Malvezzi Lupari che sostituì quella di Pietro Fieschi nel gisant, all'inizio dell'Ottocento.
Note: Of the same period as the Tartagna monument in S. Domenico 1477. / The inscription is that of one the Malvezzi family who died / in this century".

SGLT_Ftitle: Ferrara - Chiesa di S. Giorgio. Monumento al vescovo Lorenzo di Roverella. (Ambrogio Borgognoni da Milano).
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 380x312.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 328, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "This beautiful tomb which Perkins admires so much is / signed and dated: Ambrosii Mediolanensis opi 1475. / The verses beginning with: tu decus urbis were written by / Tito Strozzi. Lorenzo was the brother of Bartolomeo Roverella, the cardinal / buried in S. Clemente, Roma. Lorenzo was professor at Padua / in 1445, nuntius and legate of Calixtus and promoted in 1465 / by Pius III to the see of Ferrara. He celebrated the marriafe of Eleanor / of Aragon with duke Hercules in 1473 and died in 1474 at Monte / Oliveto. His brother transferred his remains to the church of S. George. / The reclining figure of the bishop on the monument is admirable / also the Virgin and child by the master; the 5 figures bu the scholar / are inferior, and the St. George above mediocre".
Note: This beautiful tomb which Perkins admires so much is / signed and dated: Ambrosii Mediolanensis opi 1475. / The verses beginning with: tu decus urbis were written by / Tito Strozzi. Lorenzo was the brother of Bartolomeo Roverella, the cardinal / buried in S. Clemente, Roma. Lorenzo was professor at Padua / in 1445, nuntius and legate of Calixtus and promoted in 1465 / by Pius III to the see of Ferrara. He celebrated the marriafe of Eleanor / of Aragon with duke Hercules in 1473 and died in 1474 at Monte / Oliveto. His brother transferred his remains to the church of S. George. / The reclining figure of the bishop on the monument is admirable / also the Virgin and child by the master; the 5 figures bu the scholar / are inferior, and the St. George above mediocre".

OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 380x308.
OSS_OAnotes:
Il sarcofago, che racchiude il corpo di Antonio Carafa (detto Malizia, morto nel 1437), è del sec. XIV.

Foto sup 1184, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Magnificent early renaissance tomb, under the influence of Donatello to Antonio Carrafa, called Malizia. +1438. +Magnificus dns. Malicia Carrafa, miles. obiit An. Dni. MCCCCXXXVIII. Observe him quite small presented by his Angel to the Madonna. Natorum hoc pietas struxit mihi sola sepulcrum; at which time king Alfonso brought peace back to Ausonia".
Note: Magnificent early renaissance tomb, under the influence of Donatello to Antonio Carrafa, called Malizia. +1438. +Magnificus dns. Malicia Carrafa, miles. obiit An. Dni. MCCCCXXXVIII. Observe him quite small presented by his Angel to the Madonna. Natorum hoc pietas struxit mihi sola sepulcrum; at which time king Alfonso brought peace back to Ausonia".

OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 1275, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "San Giovanni a Carbonara, Naples. Monument of Ser Gianni Caracciolo, the grand seneschal and favorite of Queen Joanna II. He was eventually murdered. The work is ascribed to Andrea Ciccione. To me it is stiff and even clumsy, but interesting as showing the passage of the Gothic to the Renaissance at Naples. 1432 is the date of the great seneschals death ...".

SGLT_Ftitle: Forli - Ginnasio. Monumento a Marcolino Amanni (Benedetto da Maiano).
OSS_Fnotes:
Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 318x381.
Nel catalogo Alinari "Terza Appendice" del 1887 la foto compare citata con un altro numero di inventario: 14774. Il numero che compare sulla foto è presumibilmente precedente.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 332, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "The blessed Marcolino was born at Forli in 1316 and died there in 1397. / He was a domenican, a reformer of his order and a great preacher. / He predicted the date of his death. / Many miracles were worked at his tomb, but he was not beatified by the Pope till 1750. / As Benedetto da Majano was born in 1442, he could not have made this work, dated 1458".
Note: The blessed Marcolino was born at Forli in 1316 and died there in 1397. / He was a domenican, a reformer of his order and a great preacher. / He predicted the date of his death. / Many miracles were worked at his tomb, but he was not beatified by the Pope till 1750. / As Benedetto da Majano was born in 1442, he could not have made this work, dated 1458".

OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 1198, verso: nota anonima manoscritta: "Tomb of Antonio da Penna secretary of king Ladislas, 1407, send to have been sculptured by Antonio Baboccio; to me it is too bad in style to be even by Baboccio and the lettering, perfect Latin except the x, makes it later then his time. Premia si meritis donant condigna superni Hic meruit superum post sua futa locum Dum vincit virtute ...".
Note: Tomb of Antonio da Penna secretary of king Ladislas, 1407, send to have been sculptured by Antonio Baboccio; to me it is too bad in style to be even by Baboccio and the lettering, perfect Latin except the x, makes it later then his time. AUTB_Fsubj_main: Scuola italiana, scuola campana, scuola napoletana
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 308x382.
Note: The great Viceroy Pietro di Toledo, who died poisoned by his son in law Cosimo in 1553, erected this monument in his life time. The Nolano who executed it must have been very old, as he was born in 1475. By the inscription the tomb was dedicated by the Viceroy Garsin, Pietros son in 1570. Pietro has also a simple monument in the Duomo of Florence".

SGLT_Ftitle: Cesena - Rocca dei Malatesta. (XV. secolo)
OSS_Fnotes:
Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 316x381.
Nel catalogo Alinari "Terza Appendice" del 1887 la foto compare citata con un altro numero di inventario: 14084. Il numero che compare sulla foto è presumibilmente precedente.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 337, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "The castle all of brick is magnificent and most extensive. / All the coats, which were enormous papal ones in terra cotta / with side scutcheon of papal legates, have been destroyed, but / a stone remains with the architects name: / MCCCCLXVI / OPUS MATHEI / NUTII PHANESIS. / This would be of Pauls 2. time. This Pope took Cesena from Roberto Malatesta. / Cesar Borgia made Cesena the capital of his duchy, the Romagna. / The Cesenati had declared him their Signore in 1500 and remained / true to him to the end of his reign. The rocca was not surrendered till August 1504, / in exchange for Cesar's liberty. But on the 20th of August the gran Capitano sent / him a prisoner to Spain. / Malatesta Novello, [...] of Pisano's medal, was lord of Cesena in 1450. / He died in 1465 and then Paul II took possessione of his lordship".
Note: The castle all of brick is magnificent and most extensive. / All the coats, which were enormous papal ones in terra cotta / with side scutcheon of papal legates, have been destroyed, but / a stone remains with the architects name: / MCCCCLXVI / OPUS MATHEI / NUTII PHANESIS. / This would be of Pauls 2. time. This Pope took Cesena from Roberto Malatesta. / Cesar Borgia made Cesena the capital of his duchy, the Romagna. / The Cesenati had declared him their Signore in 1500 and remained / true to him to the end of his reign. The rocca was not surrendered till August 1504, / in exchange for Cesar's liberty. But on the 20th of August the gran Capitano sent / him a prisoner to Spain. / Malatesta Novello, [...] of Pisano's medal, was lord of Cesena in 1450. / He died in 1465 and then Paul II took possessione of his lordship".

SGTT_OAtitle: Sepolcro di Carlo duca di Calabria
AUTB_Fsubj_main: Scuola italiana, scuola toscana, scuola senese
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 380x310.
Note: Monument of Charles the Illustrions, oldest son of King Robert. He died in 1328. He is shown clad in a royal mantle, painted blue with golden lilies. The wolf and lamb drinking at his feet in the basrelief betoken the harmony existing between nobles and people during his Government. The tomb shows Tuscan influence and is probably by a scholar of Tino da Camaino, who was in Naples from 1321 to 1333. See Perkins".

OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 317x381.

This monument is in a better style than that of her father, Duke Charles of Calabria".

OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 280x400.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 1227, verso: nota anonima manoscritta: " I have but little doubs that the Columbarium was Virgils tomb, as all events its masonry is of his period and he was certainly buried close at hand. Outside is an inscription of 1553: Qui cineres? tumuli haec vestigia: conditur olim Ille hic qui cecinit pascua, rura, duces. St. Paul visited the tomb: "Ad Maronis mausoleum Ductus, ...".
Note: I have but little doubs that the Columbarium was Virgils tomb, as all events its masonry is of his period and he was certainly buried close at hand. OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 379x316.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 346, verso: nota anonima sul verso del supporto secondario: "Ferrara. / The fortified palace of the Este family. It dates from the 14 th. cent.y / but was reduced to its present form by Duke Borso, who died / in 1471. The upper story is of still later date. / In the dungeons of the tower on the left of the photo, below the level of / the water in the ditch, were confined in 1425 Ugo d'Este and / Parisina de' Malateste. / To this palace also came Lucrezia Borgia as a bride in 1501, / and here she died in 1519".
DTZG_OAcentury: sec. XIII/ XIV,sec. XIV,sec. XV,sec. XVI
Note: Ferrara. / The fortified palace of the Este family. It dates from the 14 th. cent.y / but was reduced to its present form by Duke Borso, who died / in 1471. The upper story is of still later date. / In the dungeons of the tower on the left of the photo, below the level of / the water in the ditch, were confined in 1425 Ugo d'Este and / Parisina de' Malateste. / To this palace also came Lucrezia Borgia as a bride in 1501, / and here she died in 1519".

SGLT_Ftitle: Rimini - Tempio Malatestiano oggi Cattedrale. Lapide sepolcrale del cardinale Lodovico Bonetto d'Agrigento (XV. secolo).
SGTT_OAtitle: Lastra tombale del cardinale Ludovico Bonito
AUTB_Fsubj_main: Scuola italiana, scuola romagnola, scuola riminese
OSS_Fnotes:
Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 380x316.
Nel catalogo Alinari "Terza Appendice" del 1887 la foto compare citata con un altro numero di inventario: 15111. Il numero che compare sulla foto è presumibilmente precedente.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 351, verso: nota anonima sul verso del supporto secondario: "Rimini. Tempio Malatestiano. / Sepulchral slab of Cardinal Ludovico Bonetti; a Sicilian / from Grigenti; bishop of Amalfi, Taranto and other dioceses. / He was sent as ambassador to king Ladislas by Innocent VII / and created Cardinal by Gregory XII in 1408. / He died at Rimini en route to the Council of Constance / in sept. 1413 and was buried in the middle of the church of St. Francis. / When Malatesta converted the church into a temple some / 40 years later the tomb slab of the Cardinal was removed / and placed against the interior wall of the entrance where it / now stands. The inscription reads this...".
Note: Rimini. Tempio Malatestiano. / Sepulchral slab of Cardinal Ludovico Bonetti; a Sicilian / from Grigenti; bishop of Amalfi, Taranto and other dioceses. / He was sent as ambassador to king Ladislas by Innocent VII / and created Cardinal by Gregory XII in 1408. / He died at Rimini en route to the Council of Constance / in sept. 1413 and was buried in the middle of the church of St. Francis. / When Malatesta converted the church into a temple some / 40 years later the tomb slab of the Cardinal was removed / and placed against the interior wall of the entrance where it / now stands. The inscription reads this...".

OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 1275, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "San Giovanni a Carbonara, Naples. Monument of Ser Gianni Caracciolo, the grand seneschal and favorite of Queen Joanna II. He was eventually murdered. The work is ascribed to Andrea Ciccione. Note: San Giovanni a Carbonara, Naples. Monument of Ser Gianni Caracciolo, the grand seneschal and favorite of Queen Joanna II. He was eventually murdered. The work is ascribed to Andrea Ciccione. SGLT_Ftitle: Rimini - Tempio Malatestiano oggi Cattedrale. Fianco sinistro. (Leon Battista Alberti).
OSS_Fnotes:
Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 316x380.
Nel catalogo Alinari "Terza Appendice" del 1887 la foto compare citata con un altro numero di inventario: 15035. Il numero che compare sulla foto è presumibilmente precedente.
OSS_OAnotes:
Foto sup 384, verso: nota anonima sul verso del supporto secondario: "The occupants of the sarcophagi are: / 1. Basinio of Parma, a poet † 1457. / 2. Giusto, an orator † 1449. / 3. Gemistus Pheth, the platonist, whose bones Sigismund brought / from Sparta in 1465, as if he had been St. Marc. See Symmonds. / 4. Roberto Valturio, the military historian † 1484. 5.6.7. Later writers of Rimini- † 1579. † 1546. † 1547".

La nota riporta inoltre l'iscrizione del sarcofago di Gemistus Plethon (n. 3).

Foto sup 408, verso: nota anonima sul verso del supporto secondario: "Rimini. / Façade built by Alberti in 1450 for Sigismund Malatesta. / The marbles with which the church is decorated were plundered / from Ravenna. The church originally Gothic is dedicated to / San Francesco, but is called Tempio de' Malatesta. / Within in on his sarcophagus this grand example of a medioeval / tyrant, conquered at last by Cardinal Fortiguerra, says: [...]. / Isotta, left by Sigismund lady of Rimini, died in 1470 of fever, or of poison / administered by Roberto Malatesta, who had caused her son Sallustio, / his halfbrother, to be assasinated".
Note: The occupants of the sarcophagi are: / 1. Basinio of Parma, a poet † 1457. / 2. Giusto, an orator † 1449. / 3. Gemistus Pheth, the platonist, whose bones Sigismund brought / from Sparta in 1465, as if he had been St. Marc. See Symmonds. / 4. Roberto Valturio, the military historian † 1484. 5.6.7. Later writers of Rimini- † 1579. † 1546. † 1547".

SGLT_Ftitle: Bologna Museo Civico. Testa Greca di fianco sinistro
OSS_Fnotes:
Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 382x311.
https://collezioni.genusbononiae.it/products/dettaglio/11200
OSS_OAnotes:
Foto sup 427, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "The Lemnia at Bologna, the better of the two profiles. It was Furtwangler who took a cast of the Bologna head to Dresden and fitted it into statue 132 from the Chigi collection which, as well as N. 131, is an early marble replica of the Pheidian bronze and about identical. Of this statue 132 the right breast and the right arm were lost and have been restored bu casts from 131 [...]. Preller says she is like Schillers' Juny from Orleans [...]. In the Albertinum, Dresden, there is a cast of the headless [...] Athena quite like the Lemnia and in the Vatican, Galleria delle Statue n. 400, there is a bad replica...".

Foto sup 428, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "[...] Hatch[?] discovered the beautiful Bologna marble head shown in the foto, which they used to call an Apollo [...[ and F. Wolters that of an Amazon, whilest Pachstein was the first to pronounce her like the Lemnia".

SGLT_Ftitle: Bologna - Cimitero della Certosa. Monumento a papa Alessandro V (XV secolo)
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 380x315.
OSS_OAnotes:
Foto sup 451, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "[...] the monument is of terra cotta painted white. Is formerly stood in San Francesco under a great canopy. The art is entirely renaissance but the inscription is in Gothic letters [...]"; nota aggiunta successivamente: "It has been brought back to S. Francesco".

Il rientro del monumento funebre dalla Certosa alla Basilica di S. Francesco avviene nel 1889, nel 1893 il monumento viene ricomposto.
Note: [...] the monument is of terra cotta painted white. Is formerly stood in San Francesco under a great canopy. The art is entirely renaissance but the inscription is in Gothic letters [...]"; nota aggiunta successivamente: "It has been brought back to S. Francesco".

SGTT_OAtitle: Arca degli Antenati e dei Discendenti
AUTB_Fsubj_main: Scuola italiana, scuola toscana, scuola fiorentina
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 380x316.
Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 380x316.
OSS_OAnotes:
Foto sup 384, verso: nota anonima sul verso del supporto secondario: "The occupants of the sarcophagi are: / 1. Basinio of Parma, a poet † 1457. / 2. Giusto, an orator † 1449. / 3. Gemistus Pheth, the platonist, whose bones Sigismund brought / from Sparta in 1465, as if he had been St. Marc. See Symmonds. / 4. Roberto Valturio, the military historian † 1484. 5.6.7. Later writers of Rimini- † 1579. † 1546. † 1547".

La nota riporta inoltre l'iscrizione del sarcofago di Gemistus Plethon (n. 3).

Foto sup 408, verso: nota anonima sul verso del supporto secondario: "Rimini. / Façade built by Alberti in 1450 for Sigismund Malatesta. / The marbles with which the church is decorated were plundered / from Ravenna. The church originally Gothic is dedicated to / San Francesco, but is called Tempio de' Malatesta. / Within in on his sarcophagus this grand example of a medioeval / tyrant, conquered at last by Cardinal Fortiguerra, says: [...]. / Isotta, left by Sigismund lady of Rimini, died in 1470 of fever, or of poison / administered by Roberto Malatesta, who had caused her son Sallustio, / his halfbrother, to be assasinated".

SGTT_OAtitle: Tombe a facciata nella necropoli etrusca di Norchia

OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 30, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Tombs at Norchia near Vetralla built in imitation of temples. The entablatures were supported by columns remains of which are still in site. See Dennis, vol. I page 200. He thinks them imitations of the Greek and of circa 350 B.C. Hare says they are like miniatures of the monuments at Petra".
Note: Tombs at Norchia near Vetralla built in imitation of temples. The entablatures were supported by columns remains of which are still in site. See Dennis, vol. I page 200. He thinks them imitations of the Greek and of circa 350 B.C. Hare says they are like miniatures of the monuments at Petra".

OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 56, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "In S. Francesco of Viterbo. Tomb of Clemente IV, [died] 1268 a Franchman who reigned for 3 years in Manfreds time. It was much injured in 1798 by the soldiers of Macdonalds army; it then stood in S. M. in Gradis where it was restored by the Comte Fay de la Tour Manbourg in 1840. It was removed to S. Francesco in 1888 and restored as it now is some years later...".
Note: In S. Francesco of Viterbo. Tomb of Clemente IV, [died] 1268 a Franchman who reigned for 3 years in Manfreds time. SGLT_Ftitle: Portofino. S. Fruttuoso. Tombe dei Doria
SGTT_OAtitle: Sepolcreto dei Doria nell'Abbazia di San Fruttuoso di Capodimonte
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 380x312.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 7, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "These tombs of the Dorias are of the 12th and 13th century. Say from / 1170 to 1270. (Lettere italiche. That is pregothic. / Andreas Doria lies in the cript of San Matteo, Genova. His monument / by Angelo da Montorsoli, sarc. and angels, is rather florid. He died in 1558. / San Matteo was built by Martino Doria in 1125 and rebuilt by the Doria family / in 1278. / The great abbey was founded in the 7th Century and to it in 1000 gave the / Empress Adalgisa privileges and lands. Later on it riched over Portofino / and Sestri Levante. Finally in 1550 it was given in Commendam by Pope / Julius III to the Doria family who built about the same period the square / tower now existing (see portfolio of towers) as a protection against the Algerines".
Note: These tombs of the Dorias are of the 12th and 13th century. Say from / 1170 to 1270. (Lettere italiche. That is pregothic. / Andreas Doria lies in the cript of San Matteo, Genova. His monument / by Angelo da Montorsoli, sarc. and angels, is rather florid. He died in 1558. / San Matteo was built by Martino Doria in 1125 and rebuilt by the Doria family / in 1278. / The great abbey was founded in the 7th Century and to it in 1000 gave the / Empress Adalgisa privileges and lands. Later on it riched over Portofino / and Sestri Levante. Finally in 1550 it was given in Commendam by Pope / Julius III to the Doria family who built about the same period the square / tower now existing (see portfolio of towers) as a protection against the Algerines".

SGLT_Ftitle: Torre degli Embriaci XI secolo
OSS_Fnotes:
Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 380x313.

OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 126, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "If not of the 11th. century certainly before 1200. The tower / is nearly 140 feet high and was not cut down, when the law / truncated other towers, on account of the descent of the / Embriaci in the Crusades. By descent thro' females it came / to the family of Brignole-Sale, represented by the duchess / of Galliera. The tower is barlong. Guglielmo degli Embriaci brought the sacro catino to GEnova / as his share of the [...] of Cesarea in 1100. / He is said to have [...] / Benche ha passato in Cattaneo, Sale, Brignole Sale it is still called / of the Embriaci. The last marquis put up a tablet on it".
Note: If not of the 11th. century certainly before 1200. The tower / is nearly 140 feet high and was not cut down, when the law / truncated other towers, on account of the descent of the / Embriaci in the Crusades. By descent thro' females it came / to the family of Brignole-Sale, represented by the duchess / of Galliera. The tower is barlong. Guglielmo degli Embriaci brought the sacro catino to GEnova / as his share of the [...] of Cesarea in 1100. / He is said to have [...] / Benche ha passato in Cattaneo, Sale, Brignole Sale it is still called / of the Embriaci. OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 86, verso: nota anonima manoscritta: "Bergamo. / Monument to Bartolomeo Colleoni by Amadeo, finished by 1478. / The base is decorated with bas reliefs of the Crucifission, deposition, / etc., separated by statuettes of the virtues. / The sarcophagus itself is supported by short columns and by / Colleonis three sens in law and flanked by statues of Mars / and Hercules [...]. / Above is a gilded equestrian statue of wood of the great / Condottiero made by two Germans, Sisto figlio di Enrico Lyri / di Norimberga e Leonarodo tedesco. In was finished in 1509. / [...]. See Perkins".

It used to be called Jason and Medea, or Protesilaus and Laodamia, or anything else; now is called a funere relief, 'congedo funebre', the snake being an emblem of the dead one".
Note: Vatican Museum. Bas relief of excellent style, of pentelic marble, but much restored. It used to be called Jason and Medea, or Protesilaus and Laodamia, or anything else; now is called a funere relief, 'congedo funebre', the snake being an emblem of the dead one".

OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 381x311.
Note: She has been clothed, as the original was nude. There are even some who believe this statue to be the original of Praxiteles, but this is more than doubtful. Pope Julius wanted to put her by the side of the Apollo Belvedere. The South Kensington Museum people were allowed to have a cast of her made without her tin petticoat after promising not to reproduce her in this indelicate condition. The head does not belong to the statue. See Helbig, 316 (574). The repetition of this statue at Munich has a noseless head which Michaelis says is th finest of the Cnidian heads... "

Brera. /  Monument of Bernabò Visconti, tyrant of Milan, he of the 5000 dogs, husband of / Regina della Scala, daughter of Mastino; her mausoleum is near his. / His equestrian statue with Justice and Fortitude at its sides was put up by him / in 1370 in the high altar of San Giovanni in conca, and, on his death in 1385, / removed to his sarcophagus in the same church. [...] Bernabò's bones / are now in S. Alessandro, and his monument and that of the wife [...] on the site of which the great theatre now / stands, are in the Museo Civico".
Note: Milan. Note: Campanile of S. Satiro built about 880 by Anspert, the great bishop, who / held himself to the Popes equal and was treated by the Pope as such, / "reverendissimus et sanctissimus confrater". Ambrogio. / The church itself, which is beautiful, with a still more beautiful sacresty / is a masterpiece of Bramante built about 1485 for Ludovico Sforza, il Moro".

OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 317x380.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 773, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Museum of the Capitol. Colossal sarcophagus found in 1594 in the Monte del Grano, two miles of the Porta S. Giovanni. The reclining figures on the cover are wrongly termed Alexander Severus and Mammea. The basrelief on the 4 sides are of the good period of Roman art and represent the story of Achilles. 1. Achilles discovered amongest the daughters of Lycomedes. 2. Achilles parts from Deidamia. 3. He arms himself to avenge Patroclus [...] The Barberini vas was found inside the sarcophagus".
Note: Museum of the Capitol. Colossal sarcophagus found in 1594 in the Monte del Grano, two miles of the Porta S. Giovanni. The reclining figures on the cover are wrongly termed Alexander Severus and Mammea. The basrelief on the 4 sides are of the good period of Roman art and represent the story of Achilles. 1. Achilles discovered amongest the daughters of Lycomedes. 2. Achilles parts from Deidamia. 3. He arms himself to avenge Patroclus [...] The Barberini vas was found inside the sarcophagus".

OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 380x317.
OSS_OAnotes:
Foto sup 1909, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Porta dell'Arco. Volterra. / The masonry for the most part consists of panchina (a yellow / arenaceous tertiary full of shells), so do the doorposts (9'x 2'x 2') / of the onter arch: the imposts and voussoris are of travertine / and the three heads of a dark stone, possibly peperino, much / probably of selagite from Monte Catino with a dash of mica. / The middle head is, I think, that of a young woman, the others / those of elderly persons, male or female, probably the protecting / deities of the Etruscan city... ".

Foto sup 2276, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "La Porta dell'Arco of Volterra of Etruscan times showing the medieval truncated towers".
Note: Porta dell'Arco. Volterra. / The masonry for the most part consists of panchina (a yellow / arenaceous tertiary full of shells), so do the doorposts (9'x 2'x 2') / of the onter arch: the imposts and voussoris are of travertine / and the three heads of a dark stone, possibly peperino, much / probably of selagite from Monte Catino with a dash of mica. / The middle head is, I think, that of a young woman, the others / those of elderly persons, male or female, probably the protecting / deities of the Etruscan city... ".

LDCN_OArep: Cattedrale di S. Maria del Fiore

AUTB_Fsubj_main: Scuola italiana, scuola toscana, scuola fiorentina
OSS_Fnotes:
Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 380x318.
La stampa della foto è sicuramente antecedente al Catalogo Alinari "Firenze e contorni" 1896, dove la foto è citata con un numero di inventario diverso.
Uno scatto della medesima opera compare anche nel catalogo Alinari "Terza Appendice" del 1887 con numero di inventario: 15876.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 1922, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Firenze. Duomo. Monument to Sir John Hawkwood, one of the Black / Princes captains, who came into Italy in 1364 and went on slanghtering / and robbing and blackmailing until his death in 1394. / E la repubblica, says Gregorius, che negò sepoltura a Dante / eresse a quel ladro un onorevole monumento nel suo duomo. / There is a good story about this Messer Giovanni Augut a / due frati minori in Sacchetti's novelle. "Dio vi tolga la / vostra elemosina", answered he to them on their saying to him: / "Dio vi chà pace. / [...] / Vasari makes an amusing remark about Paolo not being / pratico con cavalli, which proves that Giorgio himself / was not so very knowing in horseship. / Hawkwood could not write; his secretary signed for him [...] H. / put his seal to the document".
Note: Firenze. Duomo. Monument to Sir John Hawkwood, one of the Black / Princes captains, who came into Italy in 1364 and went on slanghtering / and robbing and blackmailing until his death in 1394. / E la repubblica, says Gregorius, che negò sepoltura a Dante / eresse a quel ladro un onorevole monumento nel suo duomo. / There is a good story about this Messer Giovanni Augut a / due frati minori in Sacchetti's novelle. "Dio vi tolga la / vostra elemosina", answered he to them on their saying to him: / "Dio vi chà pace. / [...] / Vasari makes an amusing remark about Paolo not being / pratico con cavalli, which proves that Giorgio himself / was not so very knowing in horseship. / Hawkwood could not write; his secretary signed for him [...] H. / put his seal to the document".

SGTT_OAtitle: Palazzo del Capitano del Popolo, poi detto del Bargello
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 380x307.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 1934, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "The Palazzo of the Podestà was built about 1250-1255. / Of late years it has been completely restored, / almost rebuilt. / The tower of the Monastery of the Badia was the first / tower of the Podestà before 1250. It was then / called Bocca di Ferro, probably after the Bolognese family / of that name, then La Castagna, and is now called / Torre di Dante from being situated opposite / the back of the Poets' house. / The entrance of this house is in via S. Mrgherita. / The back door with the modern inscription is that / of the shop forming part of the Torre & Casa degli / Aldighieri. / M. Albertinelli after leaving off painting held / his inn in Dante's house".
Note: The Palazzo of the Podestà was built about 1250-1255. / Of late years it has been completely restored, / almost rebuilt. / The tower of the Monastery of the Badia was the first / tower of the Podestà before 1250. SGLT_Ftitle: Firenze. Piazza del Mercato Vecchio, detta dai Longobardi Foro del Re.
SGTT_OAtitle: Torre dei Caponsacchi nell'ex Piazza del Mercato Vecchio
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 271x403.
OSS_OAnotes:
Foto sup 1938, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "The high tower is that of the Caponsacchi (Dante) called also that of the Arnieri, / who had a tower and palazzo adjoining it. It was given to the Arte de' Medici /  and Speziali to which guild Dante belonged and has its coat in situ. / The high tower to the extreme right is said to the that of the Migliorelli".

La Piazza del Mercato Vecchio è stata completamente demolita e al suo posto è stata edificata l'attuale Piazza della Repubblica, nel contesto dei diffusi interventi urbanistici che hanno interessato Firenze dopo l'Unità di Italia.
Note: The high tower is that of the Caponsacchi (Dante) called also that of the Arnieri, / who had a tower and palazzo adjoining it. It was given to the Arte de' Medici /  and Speziali to which guild Dante belonged and has its coat in situ. / The high tower to the extreme right is said to the that of the Migliorelli".

SGLT_Ftitle: Firenze. (Mercato Vecchio) Piazza S. Andrea.
SGTT_OAtitle: Palazzo dell'Arte dei Linaioli in piazza Sant'Andrea nell'ex zona del Mercato Vecchio
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 270x400.
OSS_OAnotes:
Foto sup 1940, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "The lofty tower in the third story of which Maria Viverelli keeps her albergo / was that of the Catellini da Castiglione, mentioned by Dante. / "Ghibellini e Grandi furono quasi sempre esclusi dagli uffici." Carocci. / The Ubaldini had possession of it before them and continued to own a part / of it down to the XVIth century".

Il palazzo dell'Arte dei Linaioli e dei Rigattieri in piazza Sant'Andrea fu demolito in occasione dei rifacimenti urbanistici che interessarono tutta la zona del Mercato Vecchio, in particolare tra gli anni ottanta e novanta del XIX secolo.
Note: The lofty tower in the third story of which Maria Viverelli keeps her albergo / was that of the Catellini da Castiglione, mentioned by Dante. / "Ghibellini e Grandi furono quasi sempre esclusi dagli uffici." Carocci. / The Ubaldini had possession of it before them and continued to own a part / of it down to the XVIth century".

SGLT_Ftitle: Firenze. (Mercato Vecchio). Via dei Cavalieri
SGTT_OAtitle: Palazzo Catellini da Castiglione in via dei Cavalieri
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 402x270.
OSS_OAnotes:
Il palazzo Catellini da Castiglione è quello che si intravede sul fondo della via dei Cavalieri che la foto sup 1941 documenta.

Il palazzo fu profondamente modificato in occasioni delle pesanti demolizioni e dei rifacimenti urbanistici che interessarono tutta la zona del Mercato Vecchio, in particolare tra gli anni ottanta e novanta del XIX secolo.

AUFI_Fatelier_address: Giacomo Brogi. Fotografo Editore. Firenze. 15. Lung'Arno delle Grazie. 1. via Tornabuoni

The tower is also called Tor de' Forti from a family of that name that has a palazzo in the neighborhood".
Note: Tower of the Counts of Anguillara (Orsini) about 1070. It was surrounded by fortifications of opus saracenescum. The arc in the foreground, called Arco dell'Annunziata, has since been removed and so have [...] A few years ago a Presepio used to be annually exhibited in a room at the top of the tower at Xmas time. AUFI_Fatelier_address: V. Paganori. Firenz. Via della Scala 1
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 315x380.
OSS_OAnotes:
Foto sup 1965, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "This painted terra cotta Etruscan Lady, Larthia Seianti S... (of the family / of Sejanus) was discovered at Chiusi in 1877, brought to Rome and placed / in the Kircherian in 1878 and then removed to the Museum at Florence, / where she now is. She wears a quantity of jewelry: a fillet of flowers with / rubies and emeralds; a girdle studded with rubies; [...] / The date of this monument is said to be 217 B.C. / It cost the Government 10,000 fes. only".

Foto sup 1967, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "The painted lady came from Chiusi; the great tufo sarc. from Orvieto". Quest'ultima foto documenta l'allestimento ottocentesco della sala del Museo Archeologico di Firenze dove era conservato il sarcofago di Larthia Seianti.
Note: This painted terra cotta Etruscan Lady, Larthia Seianti S... (of the family / of Sejanus) was discovered at Chiusi in 1877, brought to Rome and placed / in the Kircherian in 1878 and then removed to the Museum at Florence, / where she now is. She wears a quantity of jewelry: a fillet of flowers with / rubies and emeralds; a girdle studded with rubies; [...] / The date of this monument is said to be 217 B.C. / It cost the Government 10,000 fes. only".

SGLT_Ftitle: Firenze. - R. Museo Archeologico. Mercurio o l'Idolino. (Bronzo antico.)
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 381x311.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 1970, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "The Idolino was found at Pesaro in 1530 and brought to Florence in her / trousseau by Vittoria della Rovere when she married Ferdinand II in 1640. / The bronze is a Greek work of the school of Myror. Its beautiful base / with an inscription by Bembo, who supposed the figure to represent / Bacchus, is a very good work of the Renaissance and made at Pesaro. / Says Collignon: [...] Ke... says the same. / [...] Furtwangler says he is of the school of Polyklet [...] Bembo makes him say: Ut potui huc veni, Delphis et fratre relicti. / Milani says: / Neither of the arms from the biceps down is original and Kedule / is of the same opinion. The right hand in particular is wooden".
Note: The Idolino was found at Pesaro in 1530 and brought to Florence in her / trousseau by Vittoria della Rovere when she married Ferdinand II in 1640. / The bronze is a Greek work of the school of Myror. Its beautiful base / with an inscription by Bembo, who supposed the figure to represent / Bacchus, is a very good work of the Renaissance and made at Pesaro. / Says Collignon: [...] Ke... says the same. / [...] Furtwangler says he is of the school of Polyklet [...] Bembo makes him say: Ut potui huc veni, Delphis et fratre relicti. / Milani says: / Neither of the arms from the biceps down is original and Kedule / is of the same opinion. The right hand in particular is wooden".

SGLT_Ftitle: Pisa - Museo Civico. Modello in legno del Pulpito già esistente nel Duomo, ricomposto nella primitiva forma dal Prof. G....
OSS_Fnotes:
Sul verso: note anonime manoscritte a matita  blu: "6706" (cancellata) e rossa: "145"; timbro a inchiostro "NF".
Una foto con il medesimo soggetto compare nella "Seconda Appendice al Catalogo Generale Alinari" 1881 con il numero di inventario: 10133. Il numero che compare sulla fascetta è sicuramente post rinumerazione del 1891-1892.
OSS_OAnotes:
Modello in scala con la prima proposta di ricostruzione del Pulpito allora smembrato, poi ricomposto diversamente da Pèleo Bacci nel 1926.

Foto sup 1996, verso: nota autografa di P.N. Ferri: "Progetto di ricomposizione del / pulpito di Giovanni Pisano. / Modello in legno già esistente / in Duomo / ricomposto nella primitiva forma / dal prof. Giuseppe Fontana".

Foto sup 2088, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Pisa. / The old pulpit of Giovanni Pisano in the Cathedral before it was / destroyed. About 1290. / Giovanni was born in 1250 and died in 1321. Amongst his most celebrated works / are the pulpit at S. Andrea, Pistoia (1298-1301), the monument of Pope Benedict XI / (who died in 1304) and that of S. Margherita at Cortona, which has disappeared. / It is doubtful whether Giovanni worked in the façade of Orvieto. tho' his pupil / Agostino da Siena certainly did".
Note: Progetto di ricomposizione del / pulpito di Giovanni Pisano. / Modello in legno già esistente / in Duomo / ricomposto nella primitiva forma / dal prof. Giuseppe Fontana".

LDCN_OArep: Cattedrale di S. Maria del Fiore
SGLT_Ftitle: Dante painted by Domenico di Michelino in 1465
AUTB_Fsubj_main: Scuola italiana, scuola toscana, scuola fiorentina
OSS_Fnotes:
Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 316x381.
Sul recto del supporto secondario, nota a matita: "2482".
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 2013, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Dante painted by Domenico di Michelino in 1465. / He shows the gates, walls and tower of Florence in the 15.th century. Also an anteport is figured. / The walls were begun in 1285 and took 100 years to complete. They formed the second circuit. / The towers, which were 76 feet high, were pulled down in 1527. / The tower of the Palazzo Publico (Palazzo Vecchio [...]) was in 1465 / and it is now".
Note: Dante painted by Domenico di Michelino in 1465. / He shows the gates, walls and tower of Florence in the 15.th century. Also an anteport is figured. / The walls were begun in 1285 and took 100 years to complete. They formed the second circuit. / The towers, which were 76 feet high, were pulled down in 1527. / The tower of the Palazzo Publico (Palazzo Vecchio [...]) was in 1465 / and it is now".

OSS_OAnotes:
Foto sup 631, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Christian Sarcophagus in the Lateran Museum representing six subjects. 1. Let little children come unto me. 2. The woman with the flux. 3. Undetermined. 4. and 5. Below, the Paralytic on his bed; above, he carrying it off. 6. Triumphal entry into Jerusalem".

La foto documenta le opere e l'allestimento ottocentesco nel Museo lateranense.
Note: Christian Sarcophagus in the Lateran Museum representing six subjects. 1. Let little children come unto me. 2. The woman with the flux. 3. Undetermined. 4. and 5. Below, the Paralytic on his bed; above, he carrying it off. 6. Triumphal entry into Jerusalem".

SGLT_Ftitle: Fonte Battesimale di Siena
AUTB_Fsubj_main: Scuola italiana, scuola toscana, scuola senese
OSS_Fnotes: Sul verso: note anonime manoscritte a matita  blu: "585".
OSS_OAnotes:
Foto sup 2016, verso: nota autografa manoscritta di N.P. Ferri: "Fonte Battesimale di Siena / principiato nel 1428 è una delle / meraviglie artistiche del Rinascimento. / E' tutto di marmo a vari colori, di / forma esagona, e ornato negli specchi di / altrettanti bassorilievi in bronzo. / 1. Il Battesimo di Cristo del Ghiberti / 2. S. Giov. in prigione idem / 3. Banchetto di Erode - Donatello [...] / Tre delle figure agli angoli - Carità / Giustizia Prudenza sono di Turino figlio / La Fede e la Speranza di Donatello / La Forza è di Goro di Neroccio. / Tre degli angioli sono di Donatello e gli / altri di Jac. della Quercia e Vecchietta".

Foto sup 2081, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "S. Giovanni. Siena. / Battistero by Giacomo della Quercia. / The bronze basreliefs are by Donatello and others".
Note: Fonte Battesimale di Siena / principiato nel 1428 è una delle / meraviglie artistiche del Rinascimento. / E' tutto di marmo a vari colori, di / forma esagona, e ornato negli specchi di / altrettanti bassorilievi in bronzo. / 1. Il Battesimo di Cristo del Ghiberti / 2. S. Giov. in prigione idem / 3. Banchetto di Erode - Donatello [...] / Tre delle figure agli angoli - Carità / Giustizia Prudenza sono di Turino figlio / La Fede e la Speranza di Donatello / La Forza è di Goro di Neroccio. / Tre degli angioli sono di Donatello e gli / altri di Jac. della Quercia e Vecchietta".

OSS_Fnotes:
Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 454x358. Foto pubblicata in
http://www.historyphotography.org/doc/MACPHERSON_FANELLI.pdf

Sul verso del supporto secondario, nota anonima a matita rossa: "1063" e a matita: "84"; sul recto, nota anonima a matita: "752".

Duomo. Siena. Monument of Cardinal Petroni
SGTT_OAtitle: Monumento funebre del cardinal Riccardo Petroni
AUTB_Fsubj_main: Scuola italiana, scuola toscana, scuola senese
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 380x316.
OSS_OAnotes:
Foto sup 573, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Duomo. Siena. / Monument of Cardinal Petroni, a sienese patrician, / made a Cardinal by Boniface VIII in 1298. He died in 1314. / The artist is said to have been either Agostino di Siena, who worked on the basreliefs of Orvieto Cathedral and / made the tomb of Bishop Tarlati at Arezzo, or else / Tino di Camaino, who made Henry VIIs tomb at Pisa in 1315. / Both the sculptors were scholars of Giovanni Pisano".

La foto documenta una ricostruzione del monumento diversa da quella attuale: in particolare mancano le cariatidi, oggi visibili a sostegno del monumento.
Note: Duomo. Siena. / Monument of Cardinal Petroni, a sienese patrician, / made a Cardinal by Boniface VIII in 1298. He died in 1314. / The artist is said to have been either Agostino di Siena, who worked on the basreliefs of Orvieto Cathedral and / made the tomb of Bishop Tarlati at Arezzo, or else / Tino di Camaino, who made Henry VIIs tomb at Pisa in 1315. / Both the sculptors were scholars of Giovanni Pisano".

SGLT_Ftitle: Volterra - Museo Nazionale. Mezza figura di un Bacco. (Scultura Greca.)
OSS_Fnotes:
Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 379x311.
La foto compare nella "Seconda Appendice al Catalogo Generale Alinari" 1881 con il numero di inventario: 10396; nel catalogo "Toscana" del 1898 con il numero di inventario che compare nella fascetta. Si ipotizza che la stampa sia stata realizzata dopo la rinumerazione delle foto Alinari del 1891-1892.

Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 316x381.
Attribuzione all'autore tratta dalla schedatura del fondo in SBN.
Dal numero di inventario si desume la datazione dello scatto post 1869 (il numero di negativo più alto di quell'anno è il 1623). Cfr. M.F. Bonetti in Un patrimonio da ordinare: i cataloghi a stampa dei fotografi, 2018, pp. 116-119.
OSS_OAnotes:
Foto sup 1909, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Porta dell'Arco. Volterra. / The masonry for the most part consists of panchina (a yellow / arenaceous tertiary full of shells), so do the doorposts (9'x 2'x 2') / of the onter arch: the imposts and voussoris are of travertine / and the three heads of a dark stone, possibly peperino, much / probably of selagite from Monte Catino with a dash of mica. / The middle head is, I think, that of a young woman, the others / those of elderly persons, male or female, probably the protecting / deities of the Etruscan city... ".

Foto sup 2276, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "La Porta dell'Arco of Volterra of Etruscan times showing the medieval truncated towers".
Note: La Porta dell'Arco of Volterra of Etruscan times showing the medieval truncated towers".

LDCN_OArep: Cattedrale dei SS. Pietro e Donato
SGLT_Ftitle: Arezzo Cattedrale. Sepolcro del beato papa Gregorio X. Margaritone
SGTT_OAtitle: Monumento funebre di papa Gregorio X
OSS_Fnotes:
Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 380x315.
La foto compare nella "Seconda Appendice al Catalogo Generale Alinari" 1881 con il numero di inventario: 9407. Il numero di inventario che compare sulla foto è presumibilmente più antico.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 616, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Tedaldo Visconti of Piacenza, of the great Milanese family, was only archdeacon / of Liege, and at Acre with Prince Edward of England, when he was elected / Pope in 1271. This noble Pope died at Arezzo in January 1276. / Margaritone who died in 1293 aged 77, can hardly have made the upper part / of the tomb, which is quite in the style of Giov. Pisano or a generation later".
Note: Tedaldo Visconti of Piacenza, of the great Milanese family, was only archdeacon / of Liege, and at Acre with Prince Edward of England, when he was elected / Pope in 1271. This noble Pope died at Arezzo in January 1276. / Margaritone who died in 1293 aged 77, can hardly have made the upper part / of the tomb, which is quite in the style of Giov. Pisano or a generation later".

SGLT_Ftitle: Pisa - Pulpito già esistente nel Duomo di G. Pisano
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 380x317.
OSS_OAnotes:
Modello in scala con la prima proposta di ricostruzione del Pulpito allora smembrato, poi ricomposto diversamente da Pèleo Bacci nel 1926.

Foto sup 1996, verso: nota autografa di P.N. Ferri: "Progetto di ricomposizione del / pulpito di Giovanni Pisano. / Modello in legno già esistente / in Duomo / ricomposto nella primitiva forma / dal prof. Giuseppe Fontana".

Foto sup 2088, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Pisa. / The old pulpit of Giovanni Pisano in the Cathedral before it was / destroyed. About 1290. / Giovanni was born in 1250 and died in 1321. Amongst his most celebrated works / are the pulpit at S. Andrea, Pistoia (1298-1301), the monument of Pope Benedict XI / (who died in 1304) and that of S. Margherita at Cortona, which has disappeared. / It is doubtful whether Giovanni worked in the façade of Orvieto. tho' his pupil / Agostino da Siena certainly did".
Note: Pisa. / The old pulpit of Giovanni Pisano in the Cathedral before it was / destroyed. About 1290. / Giovanni was born in 1250 and died in 1321. Amongst his most celebrated works / are the pulpit at S. Andrea, Pistoia (1298-1301), the monument of Pope Benedict XI / (who died in 1304) and that of S. Margherita at Cortona, which has disappeared. / It is doubtful whether Giovanni worked in the façade of Orvieto. tho' his pupil / Agostino da Siena certainly did".

SGLT_Ftitle: Sarcofago etrusco. Museo. Palermo
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 317x381.
OSS_OAnotes:
Il sarcofago proviene dalla Collezione Casuccini di Chiusi, acquistata dal Museo archeologico di Palermo nel 1865-1866.

Foto sup 1351, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "This grand headless Etruscan lady came with the other gear from the Casuccini collection of Chiusi where I saw her in 1866. She is of white marble. The figures below, painted and with painted inscriptions, are of alabaster". 

Foto sup 1352, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "All these sarch. and turns are of alabaster and come from Chiusi. The town of Palermo bought the Casuccini collection in 1866. The relief of the big sarc. represents the farewell of a married pair. He is Lavth Aphuna, she Aphunei who reclines covered with jewelry on the lid of the sarc. Awreiged female demon leads her off to the shades below [...] See Dennis Vol II, page 316".

SGLT_Ftitle: Palermo. Museo - Monumenti medioevali
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm  400x281.
OSS_OAnotes:
Foto sup 1363, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "The bodies of tufa, the heads of marble. circa 450".

Foto sup 1363, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "The marble bust on the left is that of the viceroy Don Juan Pacheco, Marquez de Vihena. The gorgeous housing is that which he pledged to the banco Municipale for 12.000 scudi, wherewith to redeem his son, a slave at Algiers. The bust of terracotta under glass is that of the celebrated poisoner of the past century, Anna Bonanno, called la Vecchia del Aceto". 

La foto documenta l'allestimento ottocentesco dell'opera all'interno di una delle sale al primo piano del Museo Nazionale di via Bara all'Olivella (oggi Museo archeologico regionale Antonio Salinas).
Note: The bodies of tufa, the heads of marble. circa 450".

Note: The bishop Baronto Ricciardi died in 1348 and, by the style, the monument / was erected shortly afterwards. His brother Bonifazio Ricciardi, / senator of Rome, 1363-64, presented by St. James, the patron of the / Cathedral, did not die till much later".

SGLT_Ftitle: Duomo of Pistoia. Monument of Cino dei Sinibaldi
SGTT_OAtitle: Monumento funebre di Cino da Pistoia
AUTB_Fsubj_main: Scuola italiana, scuola toscana, scuola senese
OSS_Fnotes:
Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 315x380.
Una foto con il medesimo soggetto compare nel "Catalogue Général des photographies" Brogi del 1878, p. 137, con il numero di inventario 4473
Sulla lastra compare la sigla: "CL".
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 786, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Duomo di Pistoia. / Monument of Cino dei Sinibaldi, born in 1270; he died in 1336 and was thus a contempo[ra]ry of Dante. / The work is by Maestro Cellini di Nese da Siena. Under a gothic baldachino, not shown in the / foto the great Master sits amongst his small disciples. The last scholar on the left is renowned / Bartolo, the last on the right is Selvaggia de' Vergolesi, Cino's love. In the basrelief the female / figure seated at the last desk represents Roman law. Petrarch sings: / "Perchè il nostro amoroso Messer Cino / Novellamente s'è da noi partito / Pianga Pistoia e i cittadini perversi, / che perdut'hanno si dolce vicino / E rallegrirsi...".
Note: Duomo di Pistoia. / Monument of Cino dei Sinibaldi, born in 1270; he died in 1336 and was thus a contempo[ra]ry of Dante. / The work is by Maestro Cellini di Nese da Siena. Under a gothic baldachino, not shown in the / foto the great Master sits amongst his small disciples. The last scholar on the left is renowned / Bartolo, the last on the right is Selvaggia de' Vergolesi, Cino's love. In the basrelief the female / figure seated at the last desk represents Roman law. Petrarch sings: / "Perchè il nostro amoroso Messer Cino / Novellamente s'è da noi partito / Pianga Pistoia e i cittadini perversi, / che perdut'hanno si dolce vicino / E rallegrirsi...".

SGLT_Ftitle: Firenze - Chiostro di S. Spirito. Monumento al Beato Neri Corsini vescovo di Fiesole
SGTT_OAtitle: Monumento funebre del beato Neri Corsini
OSS_Fnotes:
Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 380x310.
Nel catalogo Alinari "Firenze e Contorni" del 1896, la foto presenta il numero di inventario: 2402. Tale numero si intravede in controparte manoscritto sul verso della fotografia.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 841, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "The shield with the crescent between the two Corsini coats / is the coat of Fiesole of which the Beato Neri was bishop. He died in 1377".
Note: The shield with the crescent between the two Corsini coats / is the coat of Fiesole of which the Beato Neri was bishop. He died in 1377".

LDCN_OArep: Cattedrale di S. Maria Assunta in Cielo
SGLT_Ftitle: Palermo. Tomba di Costanza
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 381x317.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 1368, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "The sarcophagus is of solid porphyry; the six supporting columns of the baldachino are inlaid with gold mosaics; at the head of the sarc. an imperial crown in relief, below it a cross patonce inscribed in a circle; at the rear, above a rosette, below a single headed eagle. An old, but not contemporaneons inscription said: Caesaris Henrici latet hic [...] I saw some of these remains in the sacristy of the Duomo in 1892".
Note: The sarcophagus is of solid porphyry; the six supporting columns of the baldachino are inlaid with gold mosaics; at the head of the sarc. an imperial crown in relief, below it a cross patonce inscribed in a circle; at the rear, above a rosette, below a single headed eagle. An old, but not contemporaneons inscription said: Caesaris Henrici latet hic [...] I saw some of these remains in the sacristy of the Duomo in 1892".

LDCN_OArep: Cattedrale di S. Maria Assunta in Cielo
SGLT_Ftitle: Palermo. Tomba di Costanza
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 381x317.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 1369, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Tomb of King Roger; he + in 1154. The sarcophagus of limestone is clad with plaques of porphory and supported by white marble props adorned with kneeling Saracens, four and four; the columns supporting the baldachino are inlaid with mosaics. The old inscription said: Si fastus homines, si regna et stemmata ludunt non legum et recti sic ...".
Note: Tomb of King Roger; he + in 1154. The sarcophagus of limestone is clad with plaques of porphory and supported by white marble props adorned with kneeling Saracens, four and four; the columns supporting the baldachino are inlaid with mosaics. The old inscription said: Si fastus homines, si regna et stemmata ludunt non legum et recti sic ...".

LDCN_OArep: Cattedrale di S. Maria Assunta in Cielo
SGLT_Ftitle: Palermo. Tomba di Federico II
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 381x317.
OSS_OAnotes:
Il sepolcro era inizialmente destinato a Ruggero II (m. 1154).

Foto sup 1370, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Monument of Emperor Frederic II who died in 1250. Sarcophagus, columns and baldachino all of porphyry, the roof being supported by four colonnettes of white marble; the two brackets below, supporting the sarc. are of porphyry and consist of lions, back to back, and two by two, holding men in their paws. The cover of the sarc. has six ...".

Foto sup 1371, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "The 4 Royal tombs of: Roger +1154. Costantia, his daughter +1198. Henry VI, her husband +1197. Frederic II, their son +1250. Besides these, against the sides of the chapel is the ancient white marble sarcophagus of Costanza of Aragon, first wife of Frederic II. She died in 1222. Sicanie reginae fui Constantia ...".
Note: Monument of Emperor Frederic II who died in 1250. Sarcophagus, columns and baldachino all of porphyry, the roof being supported by four colonnettes of white marble; the two brackets below, supporting the sarc. are of porphyry and consist of lions, back to back, and two by two, holding men in their paws. The cover of the sarc. has six ...".

SGLT_Ftitle: Firenze - Chiostro di S. Spirito. Monumento di Neri di Gino Capponi (XV secolo)
AUTB_Fsubj_main: Scuola italiana, scuola toscana, scuola fiorentina
OSS_Fnotes:
Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 380x310.
Probabilmente il numero presente sulla stampa è posteriore alla rinumerazione dei negativi Alinari del 1891-1892.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 845, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Neri di Gino Capponi died in 1457. / His beautiful tomb is by some attribuited to Simone di Nanni / Ferrucci of Fiesole. This Simone is probably he who made Pope / Martini's bronze tomb in the Lateran and is wrongly called by / Vasari the brother of Donatello; he was his scholar".
Note: Neri di Gino Capponi died in 1457. / His beautiful tomb is by some attribuited to Simone di Nanni / Ferrucci of Fiesole. This Simone is probably he who made Pope / Martini's bronze tomb in the Lateran and is wrongly called by / Vasari the brother of Donatello; he was his scholar".

LDCN_OArep: Basilica di S. Miniato al Monte
SGLT_Ftitle: Firenze (Chiesa di S. Miniato). Monumento del Cardinale del Portogallo; A. Rossellino (1461).
SGTT_OAtitle: Monumento funebre del cardinale del Portogallo
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 381x316.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 847, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "This is perhaps the most beautiful of all Toscan monuments. / The chapel itself in wich it lies is most beautifully designed and / carried out. / The good young Portuguese prince, who sleeps so quietly, is made / much of by Symonds, who particularly dwells on his chastity, / a most rare virtue in the age of the renaissance. of this virtue, the unicorn, introduced into the decoration, is the emblem".
Note: This is perhaps the most beautiful of all Toscan monuments. / The chapel itself in wich it lies is most beautifully designed and / carried out. / The good young Portuguese prince, who sleeps so quietly, is made / much of by Symonds, who particularly dwells on his chastity, / a most rare virtue in the age of the renaissance. of this virtue, the unicorn, introduced into the decoration, is the emblem".

AUFI_Fatelier_address: Fratelli Alinari. Fotografi. Firenze, via Nazionale 8
SGLT_Ftitle: Firenze (contorni) Castello di Vincigliata. Sarcofago dal lato pagano. Opera del IV o V secolo. Ripristinato dall'arch. G. Fancelli sotto la direzione del propretario onor. sig. Giovanni Temple Leader
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 269x399.
OSS_OAnotes:
Foto sup 861, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "D. M. / Cascella Apol / lonia fecit / mastri Eudorom / et filie dulcissime / Lucille utrusque / enemerentibus. / The reverse of this sarc. is to be fouded with the gothic tomb"

Foto sup 919, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "In the 14th. century a Da Capponi of Pisa added a front of Christian / sculptures to a pagan sarc., which see with Roman monuments. / The subjects are the Madonna, St. Jean and S. Mary Magdalen on the sarc's / right, the angel of peace, St. John, and S. Raniero or Nicodemus, both venerated / at Pisa, on its left. 2 Pisan crosses are sculpt at its ends and beneath the Save, / is the device, an eagle and castle, of the Domini de Caprona".
Note: D. M. / Cascella Apol / lonia fecit / mastri Eudorom / et filie dulcissime / Lucille utrusque / enemerentibus. / The reverse of this sarc. is to be fouded with the gothic tomb"

I don't like the flowers and / fruits and think their colors crude. / This tomb was in 1896 brought to S. Trinità".
Note: This beautiful marble monument in a little church outside / the walls of Florence shows that Della Robbia was as / great a sculptor as a potter. I don't like the flowers and / fruits and think their colors crude. / This tomb was in 1896 brought to S. Trinità".

SGLT_Ftitle: Siracusa. Museo. Sarcofago
OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 317x381.
OSS_OAnotes:
Il sarcofago fu rivenuto il 12 giugno del 1872 nella chiesa di San Giovanni a Siracusa, durante la campagna di scavi diretta da Francesco Saverio Cavallari con lo scopo di accertare l'epoca delle catacombe presenti. 

Foto sup 1412, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Hic Adelfia C. F. posita conpar Baleri comites. This is the remarkable sarcophagus of the beginning of the 6.th century, which Cavallari found in the Catacombs in 1872. It is not Sicilian but Roman or perhaps Ravennate. Theodoric sent a commonitorium to Daniel, Marmorarius of Ravenna giving him permission to expert sarcophagi and ...".
Note: Hic Adelfia C. F. posita conpar Baleri comites. This is the remarkable sarcophagus of the beginning of the 6.th century, which Cavallari found in the Catacombs in 1872. It is not Sicilian but Roman or perhaps Ravennate. Theodoric sent a commonitorium to Daniel, Marmorarius of Ravenna giving him permission to expert sarcophagi and ...".

OSS_Fnotes: Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 310x379.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 916, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Slab tomb of Luigi Tornabuoni, knight of St. John and Grand Prior / of Pisa, made by him in 1575 in his life time , one of the finest / sepulchral monuments to be formed in Florence, or elsewhere. / It is by an unknown artist of Fiesole called "il Cecilia"".
Note: Slab tomb of Luigi Tornabuoni, knight of St. John and Grand Prior / of Pisa, made by him in 1575 in his life time , one of the finest / sepulchral monuments to be formed in Florence, or elsewhere. / It is by an unknown artist of Fiesole called "il Cecilia"".

SGLT_Ftitle: Tomba di Terone. Girgenti
OSS_Fnotes:
Fotografia incollata su cartoncino; supporto secondario mm 310x378.
La foto compare nel catalogo Sommer "Fotografie d'Italia, Malta", 1886.
OSS_OAnotes: Foto sup 1413, verso del supporto secondario: nota anonima manoscritta: "Girgenti. This of course is not the tomb of Theron, seing by Pindar, who was lord of Akragas in 488 B.C., but of some great one who lived after the restoration of the town by Timoleon in 388. By some it is thought to be a cenotaph erected by the Akragites in Timoleoris honor. He was buried at Syracuse. It seems to me later them that period".
Note: Girgenti. This of course is not the tomb of Theron, seing by Pindar, who was lord of Akragas in 488 B.C., but of some great one who lived after the restoration of the town by Timoleon in 388. By some it is thought to be a cenotaph erected by the Akragites in Timoleoris honor. He was buried at Syracuse. It seems to me later them that period".
